unnormalised: ## Beyond the Blockbusters: Why You Should Care About Film Festivals
normalised: beyond the blockbusters why you should care about film festivals

unnormalised: Hey everyone, movie buff or not, have you ever considered hitting up a film festival? We often get caught up in the big Bollywood releases or the latest Hollywood CGI extravaganza, but there's a whole other world of cinema happening at these festivals, and trust me, it's worth exploring.
normalised: hey everyone, movie buff or not, have you ever considered hitting up a film festival? we often get caught up in the big Bollywood releases or the latest Hollywood C G I extravaganza, but there is a whole other world of cinema happening at these festivals, and trust me, it is worth exploring.

unnormalised: Think of film festivals as like, the spice markets of the film world. Instead of garam masala and cardamom, you're getting a curated selection of independent films, documentaries, short films, and even animation from all corners of the globe. It's a chance to see stories you wouldn't find anywhere else, maybe even from up-and-coming Indian directors showcasing their work at the MAMI Mumbai Film Festival (happening annually, usually around October – November!).

unnormalised: So, why should you, sitting comfortably with your Netflix subscription and a bowl of popcorn, actually bother?
normalised: so, why should you, sitting comfortably with your Netflix subscription and a bowl of popcorn, actually bother?

unnormalised: First off, discovery. Imagine stumbling upon the next Anurag Kashyap, but *before* he's Anurag Kashyap. You get to witness raw talent, innovative storytelling, and perspectives that often challenge the mainstream narratives we're so used to. You might find a hidden gem, something that stays with you long after the credits roll.
normalised: first off, discovery. imagine stumbling upon the next Anurag Kashyap, but before he is Anurag Kashyap. you get to witness raw talent, innovative storytelling, and perspectives that often challenge the mainstream narratives we are so used to. you might find a hidden gem, something that stays with you long after the credits roll.

unnormalised: Secondly, it's a total cultural immersion! Festivals often host filmmakers, actors, and industry professionals, giving you a chance to interact, ask questions, and get a behind-the-scenes glimpse into the making of these films. Plus, you'll be surrounded by fellow cinephiles, discussing the movies and sharing your perspectives. It's like a massive, passionate film club meeting!

unnormalised: And finally, let's be real, it's just plain *cool*. You can brag to your friends that you saw that obscure Iranian film months before it wins some international award or gets a limited release in select theatres in Delhi or Mumbai. You’ll have stories to tell, and you'll sound super cultured.

unnormalised: Consider it, yaar. Next time the Kolkata International Film Festival rolls around in November, or the International Film Festival of India (IFFI) in Goa in late November, ditch the usual and try something different. You might just discover your new favorite film, and maybe even a new favorite director. And who knows, you might even run into someone famous – maybe even get a selfie with a "Gully Boy" star at a festival in Bandra. Think about it! It's an experience that's way more enriching than another Friday night at the multiplex.
